awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Data-driven Models of Human Mobility and Resilience for Decision Making
awd_abstract_narration:
This project envisions mobile cyber-physical systems (CPS) where people carrying cell phones generate large amounts of location information that is used to sense, compute and monitor human interactions with the physical environment during environmental dislocations.  The main objective will be to identify the types of reactions populations have to a given type of shock, providing decision makers with accurate and informative data-driven representations they can use to create preparedness and response plans. Additionally, the outcomes of this project will allow for the development of tools to assess and improve the effectiveness of different types of preparedness and response policies through feedback loops in the mobile CPS. These feedback loops could show how community behaviors during shocks change when policies are re-defined based on the computations of the CPS, and vice-versa. Previous work by the PI and others has already showed that CPS integrating people and cell phones as sensing platforms can be used to collect location information at large scale and to compute, using data mining and machine learning techniques, human mobility behaviors during shocks. However, most of the results are very limited and ad-hoc, lacking any type of serious applicability from a preparedness and response policy. This project will advance the state of the art by developing accurate methods and effective tools for decision-making during shocks in mobile CPS. From a broader impacts perspective, the proposed research will contribute in two areas: (a) real-world deployments, to promote data-driven policy development, data-driven analyses of human behavior, and the use of feedback loops in mobile CPS for decision-making assessment; and (b) the creation of an educational plan and training opportunities in the areas of data science for social good and mobile CPS for decision making.

The main outcomes of the project will include novel data-driven methods for mobile CPS that will reliably characterize and predict human mobility patterns and resilience during shocks so as to improve preparedness and response policies. The project will make use of cell phone metadata and social media to achieve the following three objectives: (1) to characterize the types of reactions that communities have to different kinds of shocks using real-time data from mobile CPS, which would allow for the development of more adequate preparedness policies to be ready for future events;  (2) to create predictive methods to forecast the impact that shock management policies would have on human mobility behaviors and community resilience during a shock,  using human behavioral information from the CPS feedback loop when different policies are applied (either in real-time or in batch processing); and (3) to evaluate the transferability of the types of reactions and predictive methods across different shocks, spatio-temporal scales and data sources in mobile CPS, which would provide decision makers with the possibility of analyzing behaviors and resilience in communities where cell phone metadata in the CPS is not fully available. From an intellectual merit perspective, the proposed methods will advance the state of the art in data analytics and real-time systems for CPS in the area of Smart and Connected Communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main objective of this CAREER award was the development of data-driven tools to support decision makers during societal shocks. Research funded by this award has 1) created novel tools and underlying models to extract human behavior insights during shocks from spatio-temporal datasets, 2) developed novel auditing and bias correction methods to enhance decision making fairness, and 3) integrated education and research efforts to train students in data science for social good.

1.Models and tools to analyze human behavior during shocks.

A central focus of this award is the analysis of human mobility patterns at societal scale during different types of shocks using spatio-temporal data from cell phones and social media. We have combined machine learning and econometric approaches to model population-level mobility patterns, and to identify behavioral responses comparing pre- and post-shock behaviors. Our research has analyzed human migrations and displacements during Mexico’s economic crisis in 2008, Tabasco’s 2009 flood in Mexico, Musanze’s 2012 flood in Rwanda, Oaxaca’s 2012 earthquake in Mexico, and La Guajira droughts in 2014 in Colombia. Our work has shown that: 1) individuals affected by shocks generally prefer to stay as close as possible to their homes, however, when forced to be displaced, they tend to move to larger cities that offer more job opportunities; 2) Social ties appear to drive displacements, with individuals favoring moving to places where they have social connections; and 3) Changes in dynamics and social communications are highly correlated to damage, with larger disruptions indicative of larger harm.

2. Models and tools to extract behavioral insights from social media to support decision making during shocks.

As part of this award, we have developed methods that combine machine learning and natural language processing techniques to extract digital communication footprints from social media (Twitter) during shocks. We have tested the efficacy of these methods in two types of shocks: natural disasters (e.g., Irma hurricane in 2017, COVID-19 in 2020) and social unrest events (e.g., Ferguson protests in 2014). Our analyses show that online behaviors can reflect the gravity of the events as they unfold in the physical space, and that citizens are much better than organizations at informally collecting and sharing real-time information on social media platforms. Our research has also showed that spatio-temporal datasets characterizing the evolution of emotions and sentiments on Twitter can forecast both vaccine hesitation and vaccine compliance at the metropolitan level over time, providing a cost-effective solution to surveys that collect vaccine perceptions (e.g., the Household Pulse Survey, HPS). Our main outcomes revealed that positive sentiments and emotions are statistically significantly related to vaccine compliance, while negative sentiments were predictive of vaccine hesitancy.

3. Novel auditing and bias correction frameworks to increase fairness of tools used for decision making.

Data-driven decision-making tools used during shocks often combine spatio-temporal data with other place-based statistics to enhance contextual knowledge e.g., case prediction models during a pandemic can use mobility data and case counts. Nevertheless, differences in cell phone ownership and social media use can affect the representativity of the underlying population, while place-base statistics can suffer from under-reporting bias. These biases can in turn affect the accuracy of the population-level insights we extract to support decision making. Research funded through this award has 1) created novel auditing frameworks to quantify data bias and the impact of data bias on tools that support decision making, and 2) developed algorithms to reduce bias and increase fairness in decision making. Our analyses have shown that mobility data does not always improve prediction performance, and that prediction improvements can be biased, revealing that larger improvements are associated with majority racial and ethnic groups thus potentially affecting the fairness of decision-making processes. Our research has also developed novel approaches to improve the fairness of prediction tools used for decision making by reducing the bias in place-based statistics via under-reporting behavior modeling.

4.  Integrating education and research.

This award has provided research opportunities in the area of computational modeling of human behavior to several PhD and undergraduate students. Through our collaborations with industry, international and non-profit organizations, students in this project have gained both a strong technical background as well as a realistic view of how the models we create can be used for social good. We have also transferred technical knowledge to our industry and international organization partners. Data and insights from this award have also been used in data science courses taught by the PI. Through semester-long projects, students have gained invaluable experience working with messy, real-world data that can have an impact in policy decisions.
